Comment: e4! the most noble of openings!

I pretty much exclusively respond to e4 with the Caro-Kann. It leads to a solid end-game position for black and i don't have to get to bogged down in theory, which i believe is the case with the Sicilian.
A standard reply.
fighting for the middle of the board.
He decides to exchange. Personally, i prefer to keep the tension in the middle but it is by no means a bad move.
developing with a check.
developing with a check.
enticing the exchange of bishops, usually in the Caro-Kann i find that i'm left with Knights on the board while exchanging bishops.
?! I've never seen this reply before...
After a short pause, i decided this was not too significant and continued with development.
And so does he.
This is all somewhat standard, aside from maybe the queen move he made.

I don't like this move. It takes away the b4 square from my bishop; however, i didn't plan on moving my bishop there in the first place. Better would of been to move the d pawn and develop the bishop.
I'm going to keep developing.
Activates the bishop and stakes a claim in the center of the board.
Getting that king nice and tucked away with his pool table. Standard opening procedure.

Pins the Knight to the queen. It isn't too big a threat by any means, but i dislike it because it keeps my queen stationed at d8 for the time being. I dislike having the integrity of my castle questioned, especially with such a nice pool table inside.
In retrospect i shouldn't of done this. It merely weakens the white squares around my castle. It was a poor attempt to shoo away the bishop.
The best reply.
My goal here was to entice the exchange of bishops. If he does exchange, i am able to develop my Knight to its usual square in this defense, as well as connect the Knights.
Excellent
